item.title: Cyberpunk 2077 Nintendo Switch 2 Physical Edition Gets First Discount
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The physical edition of one of the best third-party games for Nintendo Switch 2 is on sale for the first time at Amazon. Cyberpunk 2077: Ultimate Edition, which launched alongside the Switch 2 last June, is available for $60 (was $70). And unlike most third-party Switch 2 games, Cyberpunk 2077 comes with the full 60.6GB of game data on the card, so it won't consume 25% of your storage space like the digital edition.

It is worth noting, however, that the digital version was recently available for $40 during the eShop Holiday Sale--though Switch 2 users who shopped during the first day of the sale only paid $17.49 due to a pricing error that was honored by CD Projekt Red. Unfortunately, the digital price is back up to $70.

Cyberpunk 2077: Ultimate Edition (Switch 2)

$60 (was $70)

The Ultimate Edition comes with the base game and the excellent Phantom Liberty expansion that launched on PlayStation, Xbox, and PC in 2023.

The Nintendo Switch 2 port of CD Projekt Red's beloved open-world action-RPG is exceedingly impressive. Naturally, it's not as visually stunning as it is on PS5 and Xbox Series X. In a showdown against the Steam Deck, however, the Switch 2 edition offers a better experience as a portable game.

The graphics, animations, and overall picture clarity are impressive thanks to the Switch 2's DLSS upscaling tech, ray-tracing and HDR support, and VRR. You can pick between Quality and Performance Modes. In Quality Mode, Cyberpunk 2077 runs at a mostly smooth 30fps with 1080p resolution on handheld and docked. Performance Mode targets 40fps with 1080p resolution when docked and 720p resolution on the Switch 2's display. In handheld mode, Cyberpunk 2077 takes advantage of the screen's Variable Refresh Rate tech to maximize performance.

Cyberpunk 2077 also supports Joy-Con 2 Mouse Mode as well as motion controls if you want to try gyroscope aiming while using the wide variety of weapons and abilities you uncover in Night City. And if you already have a save file on a different platform, the Switch 2 version supports cross-progression.

CD Projekt Red's open-world RPG had an infamously poor launch back in 2020, but the studio gradually improved the experience over the next few years. The 2.0 update, which was implemented days before Phantom Liberty's launch, turned Cyberpunk 2077 from a pretty good game to an incredible one--and roughly 20-hour expansion is arguably the best piece of story content in the whole experience.

All told, Cyberpunk 2077 offers around 40-50 hours of mainline quests. With side content included, you can easily spend over 100 hours in Night City--and that's not even considering the prospect of replaying story with a different archetype and life path. Each archetype offers drastically different gameplay experiences, and your chosen backstory influences how NPCs interact with you.

More Nintendo Switch 2 Game Deals

Nintendo Switch 2 owners can save on a bunch of other third-party and first-party games at Amazon, Woot, and other major retailers. Another very impressive Nintendo Switch 2 port is Star Wars Outlaws Gold Edition, which is discounted to only $30 (was $60) and comes two story expansions and additional in-game content. Unlike Cyberpunk 2077, Star Wars Outlaws is a Game-Key Card, so you will need to download the game file once you pop the game in the console for the first time. One of Ubisoft's other big releases for Switch 2 is Assassin's Creed Shadows. Launched in December for $60, AC Shadows is on sale for the first time at Amazon.

Other notable deals include a pair of Atlus JRPGs--Persona 3 Reload for $40 (was $60) and Raidou Remastered for $30 (was $50)--and several first-party Nintendo games with free Switch 2 upgrade. Most notably, Super Mario Galaxy + Super Mario Galaxy 2 is available for $59 (was $70) at Woot.

item.title: AAA Games' Future "Lies In Smaller Teams," Says AC Unity Director
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

The creative director of Assassin's Creed Unity and Assassin's Creed Revelations, Alexandre Amancio, hasn't been shy about his belief that AAA game development is broken. Although Amancio has since left Ubisoft to serve as a senior vice president at FunPlus, he does have ideas about the future of AAA games and he believes that smaller dev teams are the way to go.

Amancio told GamesIndustry.biz that a lot of AAA studios "think that you can solve a problem by throwing people at it. But adding people to a problem stagnates the people that were already being efficient on it. It just creates a lot of variable noise ... So I think the future lies in smaller teams."

As an example of how smaller teams can collaborate on bigger projects, Amancio used Assassin's Creed: Black Flag as a hypothetical example.

"Let's say you're working on the naval system on Assassin's Creed: Black Flag," said Amancio. "That's an amazing feature you can give to a co-dev studio because it's self-contained: with good direction, you can give the co-dev studio autonomy over making it as fun as possible, as long as all of the points where it connects with the main game remain stable."

Amancio went on to say that "constraints are the secret behind any good art. And whether they're artificial or they're real constraints, they have to be imposed. Our brains are all pretty much structured the same, so given the same inputs, we'll output similar ideas ... I think ideas are important, don't get me wrong ... It's constraints that force you not to use that first idea. Sometimes it's financial or it's technical, but that forces you to find something different, and mastery and excellence exists in those decisions."

Ubisoft has yet to announce which Assassin's Creed game will be released next, but the cast of the Netflix TV series is starting to come together. There have been several reports that a remake of Black Flag is in the works, and it's reportedly called Resynced. Additionally, a mobile game called Assassin's Creed Jade is in development, as well as Assassin's Creed Codename Hexe, and a multiplayer game that may be called Assassin's Creed Invictus.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com

item.title: Arc Raiders Untended Garden Quest Guide
item.content:encoded:
GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

If you've come across the Untended Garden quest in Arc Raiders, you probably already know you're headed back into Dam Battlegrounds to seek out the Hydroponic Dome Complex. There are a few objectives that follow the initial one, though, so we've put together a guide to help you wrap it all up and get back home safely.

You don't necessarily need to extract to complete this quest, so no need to worry about bringing in your best gear or a safe pocket. You can feel comfortable going in with a free loadout to avoid risking any of your hard-earned items at the relatively busy spot you'll need to visit to finish your objectives.

When you're ready to knock out the Untended Garden quest, follow the steps below.

Access the data archive in one of the domes

Once you arrive at the Hydroponic Dome Complex on the northwestern side of Dam Battlegrounds, your objective will be to find and access a data archive in one of the domes there. Head to the southernmost dome circled on the map below. This area is frequented by other raiders, so stay frosty.

When you arrive at the dome, head inside and find a computer terminal (data archive) in the center of the building. Interact with this terminal to download the data.

Your objective will update to asking you to upload the data to a computer terminal in any Field Depot. We've got good news, though--there's one directly beside this dome, so we're heading there next.

Upload the data to the computer terminal in any Field Depot

Leave the dome using the southernmost exit to spot a Field Depot just a few steps away.

Head inside the Field Depot and interact with the computer terminal along the back wall beside the door to upload the data.

With that out of the way, you're now all set to extract. The Central Swamp Lift is the closest elevator to your location, so if it's open, that's probably your best bet. Either way, best of luck out there, raider.

For guides on Arc Raiders quests and more, check out our comprehensive guides hub.

Got a news tip or want to contact us directly? Email news@gamespot.com



https://www.gamespot.com/articles/arc-raiders-untended-garden-quest-guide/1100-6537257/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f
